title: Predicting Next-Day Wildfire Spread with Time Series and Attention
author: Saad Lahrichi (University of Missouri), Jesse Johnson (University of Montana), Jordan Malof (University of Missouri), ...
background: Next-day wildfire spread prediction involving modeling the spatial extent of ongoing wildfires using historical and environmental data to anticipate their growth.
contribution: This paper introduces the SwinUnet model for wildfire spread prediction, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy by effectively utilizing multi-day input data.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing models primarily use single-day data and convolutional architectures, limiting their predictive accuracy.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages transformer-based attention mechanisms alongside time-series data, improving prediction accuracy significantly over traditional methods.

key_innovation: Utilizes a novel transformer architecture tailored for segmentation tasks, enabling it to capture both local and global patterns in wildfire spread.
real_world_impact: Improves the accuracy of wildfire forecasting, which is critical for disaster management and resource allocation, potentially saving lives and property during wildfire events.
limitations: The SwinUnet model does not perform well when pre-trained weights are not utilized, indicating a reliance on external data sources for optimal performance.

new_terms.SwinUnet: **SwinUnet** is a transformer-based neural network designed for image segmentation tasks, known for its efficiency and capability to model long-range dependencies using a hierarchical approach.
